item.title: Trump Administration Pauses Immigration From Afghanistan After D.C. Shooting
item.description: The U.S. agency overseeing immigration made the announcement after an Afghan man shot two National Guard troops near the White House.
item.dc:creator: Hamed Aleaziz
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Law enforcement officers gathering after the shooting of two National Guardsmen in Washington, D.C. on Wednesday.

item.title: What We Know About the National Guard Shooting in D.C. and the Suspect
item.description: Two National Guard members are in critical condition after a man shot them near the White House on the eve of Thanksgiving.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Two members of the National Guard were critically wounded in a shooting near the White House on Wednesday.

item.title: Before the Shooting, Some Troops and Officials Worried About the Guard’s Safety
item.description: In an internal memo, Guard commanders warned that troops were in a “heightened threat environment.”
item.dc:creator: Campbell Robertson, Shawn Hubler and Chris Hippensteel
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of National Guard securing a federal building in Los Angeles last June.

item.title: What Is Operation Allies Welcome, the Program That Gave Some Afghans Entry to the U.S.?
item.description: The Biden administration set up the initiative after the Taliban retook power in Afghanistan in August 2021 for those who assisted U.S. troops.
item.dc:creator: Hamed Aleaziz
item.media:credit: Jon Cherry/Getty Images
item.media:description: Brig. Gen. Dan Gabrielli greeting Afghans at Holloman Air Force Base in New Mexico as part of Operation Allies Welcome in 2021.

item.title: Leaked Transcript of Witkoff Call Shows U.S. Deference to Russia
item.description: The White House envoy’s conversation suggests that President Trump is determined to make a deal to end the war in Ukraine, even if it is mostly on Russia’s terms.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Eric Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump defended his envoy Steve Witkoff’s leaked conversation as a “standard thing” that “a deal maker does.”

item.title: Trump Orders 500 More National Guard Troops to D.C. After Shooting
item.description: The president described the shooting as an “act of terror” and “a crime against humanity” and called the suspect, an Afghan national, an “animal.”
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Federal Takeover of Metropolitan Police Dept (DC)
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: A cordoned-off area near a shooting in Washington on Wednesday. President Trump ordered 500 more National Guard members to Washington after the shooting.

item.title: There have been numerous instances of violence near the White House over the years.
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla
item.media:credit: Nathan Howard/Reuters
item.media:description: The Secret Service and other law enforcement agencies investigating the box truck that crashed into security barriers at Lafayette Square, opposite the White House, in 2023.

item.title: U.S. to Press Europe and Other Allies on Immigration, Document Says
item.description: American diplomats were told to raise U.S. concerns about “violent crimes associated with people of a migration background.”
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Hamed Aleaziz

item.title: Dominican Republic Allows U.S. to Use Territory to Fight International Organized Crime
item.description: The Dominican leader, Luis Abinader, said the Pentagon could use restricted areas within the San Isidro Air Base and Las Américas International Airport for refueling and transporting equipment and technical personnel.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib and Hogla Enecia Pérez
item.media:credit: Ricardo Hernandez/Associated Press
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth at a news conference after meeting with President Luis Abinader of the Dominican Republic on Wednesday at the National Palace in Santo Domingo.

item.title: North Carolina Can Use Republican-Friendly Congressional Map, Court Says
item.description: The district court ruling means that the party is one step closer to securing another seat in the U.S. House and retaining its majority, at the urging of President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:credit: Cornell Watson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voters in Durham, N.C., last year. A panel of federal judges in North Carolina allowed the state’s newly redrawn congressional map to go into effect for the 2026 midterm elections.

item.title: What is the National Guard?
item.dc:creator: Alyce McFadden and Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: National Guard members near the site of a shooting in Washington, D.C., on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. Army Secretary’s Unusual Role in Ukraine Peace Negotiations
item.description: Daniel Driscoll has met with Ukrainian and Russian officials during a whirlwind of trips as the Trump administration pushes its latest proposal.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Anton Troianovski
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Fabrice Coffrini/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The U.S. Army secretary, Daniel Driscoll, standing, as an American delegation met with Ukrainian officials in Geneva on Sunday. Mr. Driscoll, a 39-year-old former Army lieutenant colonel, appears to be on the rise in the Trump administration.

item.title: National Guard Shooting Rattles D.C. Residents and Tourists on Thanksgiving Eve
item.description: On the eve of Thanksgiving, bystanders said the sound of gunfire was followed by anxiety over who did the shooting.
item.dc:creator: Jacey Fortin, Anton Troianovski, Michael C. Bender and Elizabeth Williamson
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Secret Service officer securing the site of a shooting near the White House on Wednesday.

item.title: Why Is the National Guard in Washington, D.C.?
item.description: The troops are deployed in the capital as part of the president’s crackdown on crime.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: US Federal Takeover of Metropolitan Police Dept (DC)
item.media:credit: Alex Kent for The New York Times
item.media:description: National Guard members have patrolled metro stations and tourist areas in Washington since President Trump deployed them in August.

item.title: Differences Over Health Care and Ukraine Roil a Chaotic G.O.P. Congress
item.description: Republican lawmakers and the White House have unloaded on one another as post-shutdown tension over policy and performance spreads across Capitol Hill.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Don Bacon, Republican of Nebraska, at the Capitol this month. He has announced he plans to retire at the end of his term in early 2027.

item.title: ‘In Triage Every Day’: A Beleaguered Speaker Says He’s Overwhelmed
item.description: In a podcast interview, Speaker Mike Johnson opened up about the crushing demands of a job that he joked was his in name only.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times

item.title: Colorado Judge Tells Immigration Agents to Stop Arrests Without Warrants
item.description: The ruling that immigration agents are acting illegally is the latest to rebuke the Trump administration’s tactics, but earlier orders have been blocked on appeal.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy
item.media:credit: David Zalubowski/Associated Press
item.media:description: Law enforcement officials during a raid at an apartment complex in Denver in February.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.description: Dozens of emergency responders and police vehicles were amassed at the corner of the shooting.
item.dc:creator: Campbell Robertson, Devlin Barrett and Hamed Aleaziz

item.title: ICE Detains Mother of White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt’s Nephew
item.description: Bruna Caroline Ferreira, the mother of a nephew of the White House press secretary, Karoline Leavitt, was pulled over and arrested on her way to pick up her son from school, Ms. Ferreira’s lawyer said.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman who was brought to the United States as a child and was once engaged to Karoline Leavitt’s brother has been detained at an Immigration and Customs Enforcement facility in Louisiana.

item.title: Northwestern University Nears Deal to Resolve Its Conflict With the White House
item.description: The school, one of several to face pressure campaigns from the Trump administration, would pay a $75 million fine and have its research funding restored under terms of the agreement being discussed.
item.dc:creator: Michael C. Bender, Michael S. Schmidt, Alan Blinder and Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Mustafa Hussain for The New York Times
item.media:description: Northwestern University has endured months of pressure from the White House and Republicans in Congress, who have accused the school of not doing enough to address antisemitism.

item.title: For Spouses of U.S. Citizens, Green Card Interviews End in Handcuffs
item.description: Agents are arresting foreign-born spouses when they report for the final step to obtain permanent residency, and charging them with visa violations that could result in deportation.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan and Ariana Drehsler
item.media:description: Stephen Paul had to take a leave from his job at the San Diego County Sheriff’s Department to care for his child while his wife was detained by ICE.

item.title: Supreme Court Defers Ruling on Trump’s Effort to Oust Copyright Official
item.description: An appeals court panel had said that Shira Perlmutter, the head of the U.S. Copyright Office, could remain in her role as an adviser to Congress.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow
item.media:credit: Jared Soares for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shira Perlmutter, who was appointed in 2020 by the librarian of Congress, oversees the government’s copyright office and administers the nation’s copyright system.

item.title: State Court Rules School Vaccine Law Can’t Bar Religious Exemptions
item.description: The decision was handed down by a judge in West Virginia, which has one of the country’s strictest school vaccination laws and one of the highest vaccination rates.
item.dc:creator: Campbell Robertson
item.media:credit: Christopher Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: Requests for vaccine exemptions involving children have increased in the United States in recent years.

item.title: Judge Dismisses Georgia Election Interference Case Against Trump
item.description: The president has now seen three criminal cases against him dissolve since he was re-elected last year.
item.dc:creator: Richard Fausset and Danny Hakim
item.category: Georgia Criminal Case Against Trump (2020 Election)
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump was booked at the Fulton County jail in Atlanta in August 2023.

item.title: Trump Defends Witkoff’s Tactics in Russia-Ukraine Peace Talks
item.description: President Trump said the envoy, Steve Witkoff, was using standard negotiating methods, after he appeared to coach a Russian official in a leaked call.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Steve Witkoff with President Trump in the Oval Office earlier this year. Mr. Witkoff is set to meet with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia as the U.S. seeks a deal to end the war in Ukraine.

item.title: Detroit Has Its Own Thanksgiving Parade. The City Gets Bigheaded About It.
item.description: The march down Woodward Avenue, which endured through the city’s hardest years, features papier-mâché caricatures that are uniquely Detroit.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith and Nick Hagen
item.media:credit: Nick Hagen for The New York Times

item.title: Fact Check: Is Trump Right About Affordability?
item.description: President Trump has made misleading statements about the cost of a Thanksgiving meal, turkey and gasoline.
item.dc:creator: Linda Qiu, Claire Hogan, Stephanie Swart and Pierre Kattar

item.title: SNAP Recipients Plan Thanksgiving, Down to Their Last Cent
item.description: Mary Schiely relies on SNAP benefits, as do many customers at the small grocery store where she works. The nation’s day of feasting is not the easiest for them.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Williams, Audra D. S. Burch and Madeleine Hordinski
item.media:credit: Madeleine Hordinski for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mary Schiely works at a market that serves customers on SNAP benefits. She is also a recipient of the food benefits program herself.

item.title: What the Pentagon’s Attack Videos Reveal About the Boat Strikes at Sea
item.description: The military has released 21 video clips of U.S. attacks on vessels it says are trafficking drugs. But they tell only part of the story.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay, Brent McDonald and Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
